title: Anime Site Collaboration Project Vol. 21: MAPPA
body:
Japanese anime has taken the world by storm more than ever before.

We conducted an interview with an anime production studio called MAPPA to find more about their passion about anime and their exclusive stories behind anime production.

This is a large-scale project with the collaborative efforts of anime news websites throughout the world. These websites include Anime! Anime!, an anime information website, Tokyo Otaku Mode, which has more than 20 million followers on Facebook, and Bahamut, a major company based in China.

Please check out our full list of interviews here.
******************************************

MAPPA‚Äôs representative works: In this Corner of the World, Kids on the Slope, Terror in Resonance, Yuri!!! on ICE, Rage of Bahamut Genesis, Zombieland Saga, Dororo, Banana Fish, Dorohedoro, and Listeners.

In 2011, Masao Maruyama, who had resigned from animation studio Madhouse, established MAPPA at the age of 70. In the following year, MAPPA drew more attention from its originality and high-quality performance by continuously producing TV anime series, such as Kids on the Slope and Teekyu.

In April 2016, Manabu Otsuka, one of the founding members, became MAPPA‚Äôs next president. Within that same year, Director Sunao Katabuchi‚Äôs animation feature film, In this Corner of the World, was released. The film‚Äôs production funds were raised by crowdfunding and became a success. It remained in theaters for a national record of 1,173 consecutive days and sold more than a total of 2.1 million tickets, which successfully earned a box-office revenue of more than 27 million yen.

MAPPA continues to produce high-quality works by collaborating with famous directors such as Sunao Katabuchi, Shinichiro Watanabe, and Sayu Yamamoto.

In this interview, Ms. Fuko Noda, the head of the production department who works under current president Manabu Otsuka, talks to us about the company‚Äôs future plans in detail.

(Interview/composition by Minako Nakamura, filmed by Sota Obara).





A studio formed of people with strong aspirations to produce new and exceptional works yet to be seen in the world.

‚ÄîWhat led to the establishment of MAPPA?

Otsuka: MAPPA ( Maruyama Animation Produce Project Association ) is originally a company that Maruyama, who had resigned from Mad House, wanted to establish in order to somehow release In This Corner of the World with Director Sunao Katabuchi.

Maruyama‚Äôs close connection, Director Soichiro Watanabe, then joined the company which also led to the production of multiple TV series.

The staff that joined MAPPA at the time, including myself, all joined because we wanted to work with Mr. Maruyama, Mr. Katabuchi, and Mr. Watanabe.

‚ÄîWhat was the studio‚Äôs atmosphere like when it was initially founded?

Otsuka: You can say that it was like a group of rowdy pirates (laughs). Before coming to MAPPA, I had been working under Studio4‚ÑÉ‚Äôs Ms. Eiko Tanaka so I was frequently shocked by the difference between studios.

However, I noticed that the company was not too concerned with the specific details. MAPPA had this old-fashioned mindset that supported the idea of "as long as we produce excellent anime, everything else doesn‚Äôt matter too much".

It felt like we were running against the wind because we had many people quitting their previous job to produce "exceptional" anime with Katabuchi and Watanabe.

‚ÄîFollowing Madhouse, MAPPA is also known for producing high-quality anime. What are the things that you took over from the Founder Mr. Maruyama?

Otsuka: His mindset of "difficult requests are fulfilled with difficult aspirations". This means that obstacles in front of us may be tough and intimidating, but facing them could help you discover new ideas or accomplish something unexpectedly.

This anticipation of finding new discoveries is what I have learned from both Mr. Tanaka from STUDIO4‚ÑÉ and Mr. Maruyama. They were similar in that aspect. That is something that I am aiming to accomplish.

‚ÄîOne of the goals behind the establishment of MAPPA was to produce Director Katabuchi‚Äôs In This Corner of the World. How did you respond to his demands?

Otsuka: What I mean by the word "difficult", as I mentioned earlier, are things that you cannot do normally. Director Katabuchi‚Äôs works were "difficult" because their plays were very detailed which required many video recordings.

We understood the purpose behind this after his explanations. However, every time we completed a scene, we were not sure if we had fulfilled all his goals. Mr. Katabuchi‚Äôs thought process is far beyond our own.

Mr. Katabuchi spent his entire life to arrive at this stage, so we understood that this is not what younger generations like us can accomplish easily. We were desperately trying to keep up with him.

In September 2019, Contrail Corporation was founded as a studio for Mr. Katabuchi‚Äôs next anime, and we intend to improve that aspect of the anime production.

‚ÜíNext page: ‚ÄúEnjoyable‚Äù is the most important driving force.

title: Boruto to Resume Broadcasts On Jul. 5!
body:
Ninja anime Boruto: Naruto Next Generations will begin broadcasting new episodes again on Jul. 5!

The show went on hiatus in April due to the effects of the coronavirus pandemic. With its return to the airwaves, the hotly anticipated Kara arc, which sees Boruto take on new duties in Valley Country, will begin on Jul. 19.

Two additional cast members have been announced: Cho as the mysterious Victor, a Kara member, and Kakihara Tetsuya as Deepa, another member.

Director Kouda Masayuki has released a series of illustrations to celebrate the show's return.

Boruto: Naruto Next Generations follows the adventures of legendary ninja Naruto‚Äôs son, building on the success of the 2015 anime movie, Boruto: Naruto The Movie.

Boruto: Naruto Next Generations resumes on Jul. 5. The Kara arc airs from Jul. 19.

title: Fate/stay night: Heaven's Feel III. spring song to Open in August!
body:
Upcoming anime movie Fate/stay night: Heaven's Feel III. spring song is now set to open at cinemas across Japan on Aug. 15!

Originally scheduled for Mar. 28, the opening date was delayed twice. Advance tickets purchased previously will still be honored when the film opens later this summer.

Following presage flower in 2017 and lost butterfly in 2019, spring song is the third and final instalment in the movie trilogy adapting the Heaven‚Äôs Feel route of the original Fate/stay night game.

title: Studio Trigger and CD Projekt Red Team Up For Cyberpunk Netflix Anime!
body:
Studio Trigger is teaming up with Polish game studio CD Projekt Red for Cyberpunk: Edgerunners, an original anime series set in the world of upcoming video game CyberPunk 2077!

The 10-episode series is slated to stream on Netflix in 2022. Set in a vast city where technology and body modification are commonplace, it follows a boy named Youhei. From the difficulties and sacrifices that he experiences, he goes on to become a ‚ÄúCyberpunk‚Äù outlaw.

Studio Trigger co-founder Imaishi Hiroyuki ( Gurren Lagann, Kill la Kill, [ Promare ) will direct with Otsuka Masahiko ( Gurren Lagann, FLCL ) as assistant director. Yoshinari Yoh ( Little Witch Academia, BNA: Brand New Animal ) and Kaneko Yuto ( Little Witch Academia ) will handle character design and Wakabayashi Hiromi ( Kill la Kill ) will serve as creative director, while Usa Yoshiki will provide series composition. Silent Hill‚Äôs Yamaoka Akira will compose the score.

Cyberpunk: Edge Runners will stream on Netflix in 2022.

Adapted with permission from Anime!Anime!

title: Violet Evergarden Movie Confirms September Release Date!
body:
The twice delayed Violet Evergarden: The Movie has announced a new release date of Sept. 18!

A trailer featuring the theme song, "WILL" by anisong singer True, was released along with the announcement.

Adapted from the series of light novels by Akatsuki Kana, the franchise revolves around the titular Violet Evergarden, a former soldier who has transitioned to a role as an ‚ÄúAuto Memory Doll‚Äù scribe.

The upcoming movie is an original sequel to the TV anime which aired in 2018. It will follow Violet as she goes through life, still unable to forget about her former employer Gilbert. One day, she meets his older brother Dietfried, who tells her that she should forget about Gilbert and move on.

Originally scheduled for release on Jan. 10, it was first delayed after a fire at a Kyoto Animation studio, and again due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Advance tickets purchased for the previous release dates will still be valid when the movie opens in September.

Violet Evergarden: The Movie is slated to open on Sept. 18.

Idol anime A3! has released a new visual featuring the next season's Autumn Troupe!

title: Yuasa Masaaki's INU-OH Joins Annecy Animation Festival's Work in Progress Program!
body:
Acclaimed director Yuasa Masaaki's latest animated feature, INU-OH, has been selected for the Work In Progress Features program at this year‚Äôs Annecy International Animated Film Festival!

Based on the novel by Furukawa Hideo Heike Monogatari Inu-Oh no Maki (The Tale of the Heike, Inu-Oh‚Äôs Episode), the movie tells the story of all but forgotten 14th century Sarugaku Noh performer Inu-Oh. Born with physical disfigurements and forced to cover his face and body, the cheerful boy nevertheless goes on to become friends with a blind biwa player named Tomona and make his way to Noh stardom.

As part of the program, an exclusive introductory video is available on the Annecy 2020 online platform. Not only does Yuasa himself outline the origins of the project, but he also showcases parts of the animation tests and character designs by their creator, Matsumoto Taiyou.

INU-OH is scheduled for a theatrical release in Japan in 2021.

The 2020 Annecy International Animated Film Festival is running online until Jun. 30.

title: Tokyo Revengers Gets Anime Adaptation For 2021!
body:
Action manga Tokyo Revengers is getting an anime adaptation to be broadcast in 2021!

Written by Wakui Ken, Tokyo Revengers follows former delinquent (and now total loser) Takemichi. A day after learning that his middle school sweetheart and one true love Hinata has been murdered by the Tokyo Manji Gang, he is pushed off a train station platform to his death. Waking up 12 years in the past, Takemichi soon decides that he must save Hinata by changing their future.

Wakui has penned a celebratory illustration of Takemichi, Mikey, Draken, Baiji, and Kazutora, which was also featured in the teaser trailer below.

Tokyo Revengers is slated to air in 2021.

title: Sailor Moon Eternal Release Delayed to 2021
body:
Upcoming two-part movie Sailor Moon Eternal is postponing its release date due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Part 1 has been delayed from Sept. 11 to Jan. 8, 2021, while Part 2 is set to open on Feb. 11. A new teaser trailer has also been released with the updated release dates.

In an official statement, Toei offers its sincerest apologies to those looking forward to the movie.

Sailor Moon Eternal is the iconic magical girl franchise's latest movie. Taking the place of a fourth season for the recent Sailor Moon Crystal TV anime, it begins on the day of the century‚Äôs biggest solar eclipse, when Tsukino Usagi and Chibiusa are approached for help by Pegasus/Helios.

Sailor Moon Eternal will now open at Toei Cinemas locations across Japan on Jan. 8 (Part 1), and Feb. 11 (Part 2).

title: Studio Ghibli‚Äôs Aya and the Witch Reveals First Stills!
body:
Studio Ghibli has debuted its first visual and a series of stills for Aya and the Witch, its very first CG movie!

Miyazaki Gorou, the son of Studio Ghibli co-founder Miyazaki Hayao, is directing the new feature. It is adapted from fantasy novel Earwig and the Witch, written by the late Diana Wynne Jones, whose Howl's Moving Castle inspired a much-loved Ghibli film of the same name.

The story follows a young girl who grows up without knowing that she is the daughter of a witch. One day, she is brought back to a strange house to live with a mean witch.

The film was set to premiere at the now canceled Cannes Film Festival and is now destined for broadcast on NHK this winter.

As the movie's director, Miyazaki commented that he hopes the movie will give encouragement to children and cheer up adults, two groups who might often find themselves at odds against the backdrop of Japan's ageing population.

title: The God of High School Releases Visual and Trailer Featuring Theme Songs!
body:
Upcoming anime The God of High School has released its latest key visual along with a trailer featuring the opening and ending theme songs!

The key visual and trailer star protagonist Jin Mori (played by Tachibana Tatsumaru) with fellow competitors Han Daewi (Kumagai Kentarou), and Yoo Mira (Ohashi Ayaka). The trailer also showcases the series‚Äô opening theme by KSUKE, ‚ÄúContradiction (feat. Tyler Carter)‚Äù, and the ending theme by CIX, ‚ÄúWin‚Äù.

Based on the South Korean web manhwa by Park Yongje, the series follows self-proclaimed ‚Äústrongest high schooler‚Äù Jin Mori. He is summoned to the God of High School tournament, where the strongest fighters gather in hopes of winning a certain prize - the fulfilment of a wish with no questions asked.

The God of High School airs from Jul. 6.

title: Mashima Hiro's Edens Zero Gets Anime Adaptation!
body:
Fantasy manga Edens Zero, the latest title from Fairy Tail's Mashima Hiro, is getting a TV anime adaptation!

Edens Zero has been serialized in Weekly Shonen Magazine since 2018. The story follows Shiki, a young man living alongside machines on a planet named Granbell. After a B-Cuber (or content creator) named Rebecca,and her cat companion Happy visits, Shiki finds himself on an adventure through the universe, searching for a legendary goddess.

Mashima has expressed his excitement for the upcoming adaptation, commenting that he looks forward to seeing the Sakura Cosmos and Ether Gear battle scenes.

title: Re:Zero Season 2 to Air From July 8!
body:
Popular anime Re:Zero will be back on the airwaves with Season 2 from Jul. 8!

A key visual and trailer has been released, along with character settings.

In addition to the key visual and trailer, the show has also released a series of character settings including: Otto Suwen (Amazaki Kouhei), Petra Leyte (Kouno Marika), Frederica Baumann (Nazuka Kaori), Garfiel Tinsel (Okamoto Nobuhiko), Lewes Meyer (Takana Aimi), and Echidna (Sakamoto Maaya).

Adapted from the series of light novels written by Nagatsuki Tappei with illustrations by Otsuka Shinichiro, the franchise follows a young man, Natsuki Subaru, who is suddenly transported to another world on his way home from the combini and discovers that he has the ability to rewind time by dying.

The first cour of the Season 2 will air from Jul. 8, with the second cour airing in Jan. 2021.

title: Shaman King Gets Anime Reboot For 2021!
body:
Popular adventure manga Shaman King is getting an anime reboot airing from Apr. 2021!

While staff and cast details are yet to be released, the reboot will adapt the original 35 volumes of Takei Hiroyuki's iconic manga.

Shaman King follows a young shaman named Asakura Yoh, who has his sights set on becoming the Shaman King. To achieve this, Yoh embarks on a journey to win the Shaman Fight contest. The latest arc, Shaman King the Super Star, is currently running in Monthly Shonen Rival.

The Shaman King reboot anime will air in 2021.

title: Bandai Namco Arts and Eight Bit to Begin Partnership With That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime Anime!
body:
Bandai Namco Arts and Eight Bit have announced an official business partnership!

Having collaborated on many projects in the past, including the anime adaptation of That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime, the two companies will also team up for Season 2 and spin-off anime The Slime Diaries: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime under the new deal.

The partnership's objective is to create specialist production pipelines, advance projects by young producers and share personnel. Bandai Namco Arts aims to make use of Eight Bit‚Äôs existing franchises to strengthen their production capabilities, while Eight Bit hopes to expand its business with the aid of Bandai Namco‚Äôs knowledge and connections.

[ That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime](](https://otakumode.com/shop/label/That%20Time%20I%20Got%20Reincarnated%20as%20a%20Slime) Season 2 Part 1 airs in Jan. 2021, with Part 2 airing the following July. The Slime Diaries: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime airs in Apr. 2021.

title: Attack on Titan Reveals Season 4 Trailer!
body:
Popular anime Attack on Titan has released a trailer for its upcoming fourth season, titled The Final Season!

MAPPA will be taking over to produce from Wit Studio, who handled the first three seasons. Hayashi Yuichirou is set to direct.

Original author Isayama Hajime issued a statement thanking director Araki Tetsurou and WIT STUDIO for all the happy memories from the last decade, while saying that he looked forward to making new ones with MAPPA.

New director Hayashi expressed his excitement and vowed to do his best to maintain the high quality the series is known for.

A special re-edit of the 59 episodes already aired, Attack on Titan: Chronicle, is currently scheduled for a limited theatrical run from July 17.

body:
Upcoming movie Evangelion: 3.0+1.0 Thrice Upon a Time has released its second teaser trailer!

Evangelion: 3.0+1.0 is the fourth and final installment in the Rebuild of Evangelion movie series, produced by Studio Khara as a remake of the 1995 anime Neon Genesis Evangelion. title: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime Delays Season 2 and Spin-off
body:
That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime has delayed the broadcast of its second season and spin-off anime Slime Diaries: That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime due to the effects of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

The first part of Season 2 will now air in Jan. 2021 with the second part following in July, while Slime Diaries will now air in April. Via a statement on the official site, the production team offered their profound apologies and asked for fans‚Äô understanding.

Season 2 was originally scheduled for broadcast from October this year, with the second half from Apr. 2021. The spin-off was slated to air in Jan. 2021.

Originally a light novel series by Fuse and Mitz Vah, That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime follows a salaryman who is stabbed to death and subsequently reincarnated as a slime in another world. Taking on the name Rimuru, he tries to create a society in which all species can live together happily. The first season of the TV anime was broadcast from Oct. 2018 to Mar. 2019.

Rap project Hypnosis Mic's TV anime adaptation will be hitting the airwaves on Oct. 3!

body:
Upcoming anime Jujutsu Kaisen has released its first key visual!

The visual features protagonist Yuji and Sukuna, the "King of Curses", standing in front of the Malevolent Shrine.

Original author Akutami Gege has released an illustrated statement. Telling fans that he had gotten a sneak peak at storyboards from episode one, he also assured otaku that they should be drooling with anticipation.

Director Park Sunghoo commented that he would do his best to elevate the work to even greater heights through the anime with the essence of the original manga's characters and the cast's acting, also including an illustration.

Serialized in Weekly Shonen Jump since Mar. 2018, Jujutsu Kaisen follows an unnaturally athletic high schooler named Itadori Yuji. After he joins his school's occult club, he unwittingly comes in contact with a cursed talisman and finds himself possessed by an evil spirit.

Jujutsu Kaisen is slated to air in Oct. 2020.

title: The Day I Became a God to Star Sakura Ayane!
body:
Voice actress Sakura Ayane is set to take the lead role of The Day I Became a God, the latest anime collaboration between Key, Aniplex, and P.A. Works.

Sakura Ayane, who played Charlotte‚Äôs Tomori Nao, will voice, Hina, a young girl who becomes a goddess. Having seen the end of the world, Hina chooses a boy to spend the rest of time with.

The Day I Became a God airs in October.

title: Non Non Biyori to Return in 2021!
body:
Slice-of-life anime Non Non Biyori will be returning for a third season titled Non Stop in Jan. 2021!

The recently released key visual features central characters Renge, Hotaru, Natsumi, and Komari in the midst of the lush countryside.

The girls' original voice actresses, Koiwai Kotori, Murakawa Rie, Sakura Ayane, and Asumi Kana, are set to reprise their roles for the new season. In addition, Nazuka Kaori will be back as Kazuho Miyauchi, Satou Rina as Kagayama Kaede, Fukuen Misato as Miyauchi Hikage, and Shintani Ryouko as Fujimiya Konomi, while Koshigaya Suguru is again credited with a "????"

The following staff members will also return: Kawatsura Shinya as director, Yoshida Reiko for series composition, and Otsuka Mai for character design. Kusanagi is to provide background art again, while Silver Link will produce.

Adapted from Atto's manga of the same name, Non Non Biyori follows four friends and their life in a rural village. The first season aired in 2013, with Season 2 airing in 2015.

Non Non Biyori Season 3 is slated to air sometime in Jan. 2021.

title: Baki the Grappler Teases Raitai Tournament Arc With Poster & PV!
body:
Netflix anime Baki the Grappler has released a new key visual and main trailer for its upcoming second season!

Based on Itagaki Keisuke's classic fighting manga, the series follows Hanma Baki, the youngest underground fighting champion, and his father and rival Yujirou, also known as "the strongest creature on earth".

Season 1 of the anime launched on Netflix in 2018. Season 2's The Great Raitai Tournament arc will see Baki enter the Raitai tournament, an extreme Chinese martial arts competition held once every 100 years. title: Fate/kaleid liner Prisma Illya Announces New Movie!
body:
Fate spin-off Fate/kaleid liner Prisma Illya is set to head back to the big screen!

While the premiere date is yet to be confirmed, both a celebratory visual and PV by original author Hiromaya Hiroshi have been released.

Fate/kaleid liner Prisma Illya began as a manga in 2007, transforming Illyasviel von Einzbern (first featured in Fate/stay night ) into a magical girl. With the Holy Grail War having already been prevented, Illya grows up in relative peace, but soon finds herself on a mission to collect the seven Class Cards under the supervision of sorceress Tohsaka Rin.

The TV anime adaptation first aired in 2013, and went on to receive four seasons altogether. Other works include a movie titled Fate/kaleid liner Prisma Illya: Oath Under Snow, and an OVA titled Prisma Phantasm, as well as a popular game and series of novelisations.

title: Inuyasha Back With Sequel Set For Autumn 2020!
body:
Classic manga Inuyasha is getting a spinoff anime set for broadcast this fall!

Titled Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon, the sequel will follow the daughters of Inuyasha and his half-brother Sesshoumaru: Towa, Setsuna, and Moroha.

Half-youkai twins Towa and Setsuna are separated after the former accidentally travels from the Sengoku period to present-day Japan through a mysterious tunnel, and is taken in by Kagome's brother. Left in the past, Setsuna comes to work as a demon slayer under Kohaku.

Meanwhile, Moroha, the daughter of Inuyasha and Kagome, also spends her days slaying demons. Ten years after Towa's sudden departure, the tunnel once again opens and the other two girls also find themselves in the present-day. But despite the twins' reunion, Setsuna has no memory of her long-lost sister.

Satou Teruo will direct the spinoff, with Sumisawa Katsuyuki for series composition and original author Takahashi Rumiko for main character design. Hishinuma Yoshihito will handle animation character design, and Wada Kaoru will provide music. Sunrise is set to produce the anime.

Beginning with Takahashi Rumiko's popular fantasy manga, the story of Inuyasha unfolds between the present and the Sengoku Era, in which yokai run rampant. The original TV anime adaptation began in 2000, leading to four theatrical movies.

In celebration of the announcement, the May 13 issue of Weekly Shonen Sunday will come with a bonus Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon poster illustrated by Takahashi Rumiko.

(C) Takahashi Rumiko / Shogakukan, Yomiuri TV, Sunrise 2020

title: Higurashi When They Cry Releases Main Character Intros!
body:
The rebooted Higurashi When They Cry TV anime has released a series of character introductions featuring Maebara Keiichi, Ryugu Rena, Houjou Satoko, Furude Rika, and Sonozaki Mion!

Maebara Keiichi, played by Hoshi Souichirou, is a boy who has just moved to the village from the city. Naturally curious and possessing a hot-blooded spirit, he comes to discover that his new residence is home to a terrible mystery.

Ryugu Rena, played by Nakahara Mai, is Keiichi's classmate. With a huge love of cute things, she tends to take them home upon discovery.

Houjou Satoko, played by Kanai Mika, is a girl in the class below Keiichi and Rena. With a posh yet grammatically strange accent, she is extremely competitive but also has a cheeky side to her.

Furude Rika, played by Tamura Yukari, is a strange girl who plays the miko role at the local Watanagashi Festival every June. She sometimes displays a calmness beyond her years.

Sonozaki Mion, played by Yukino Satsuki, is a girl in the class above Keiichi and Rena. Despite her tendency to talk like an old man at times, she is loved by all around her for her caring disposition.

Higurashi When They Cry's TV anime reboot airs from July.

title: Kubo Tite's Burn the Witch Gets Anime Movie For Autumn!
body:
Bleach author Kubo Tite's newest work Burn the Witch is getting an anime movie adaptation set to open this autumn!

A key visual and trailer have been released, bringing the world of Ninny and Noel in "reverse London" to life.

The movie will be directed by Kawano Tatsurou ( Psycho-Pass, Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress ), while Studio Colorido ( Penguin Highway ) will produce with Team Yamahitsuji, an animation team created by Kawano.

body:

title: Anime Tamago Reveals Stories For Its 2020 Shorts!
body:
Japan's Agency for Cultural Affairs launched Anime Tamago in 2010 to support aspiring animators, and it's still going strong. Ometeotl‚â†HERO

Ometeotl‚â†HERO depicts Earth in 2220, where new species have been born as a result of inhabitants being welcomed from different planets to compensate for the declining population. On his 18th birthday, Yuki, a son of the Hero tribe, finds out that his father is a Hero, but his mother is from a tribe with the power to manipulate plants, which was wiped out by the increasing mechanisation of the ecosystem. Having inherited the powers of both, Yuki must decide how to use them.

The Chronicles of Rebecca

10-year-old Rebecca is the second eldest of seven siblings living in late 19th century Maine. After her father‚Äôs death impoverishes the family, Rebecca is sent to live with two of her aunts, Miranda and Jane. Though Rebecca becomes fond of her kind Aunt Jane, she shrinks from the strict and nagging Miranda. One day, Rebecca is scolded by Miranda for wearing outside the pink dress Jane made for her. In a fit of anger over being insulted about her father's death, Rebecca decides to run away.

Michiru Rescue!

Four orbs - Blue, Yellow, Silver, and Purple, fly through space chasing an orb of Dark Red. After a lengthy battle, only the Blue reaches the Earth, falling into the room where Michiru is peacefully sleeping. The Dark Red also appears on Earth but takes the form of a young boy and goes on to boost the numbers of illegally raised warbling white-eye birds. One day at a market in the park, Michiru witnesses the birds attacking people. Despite the efforts of the Yellow, Silver, and Purple orbs, a fierce battle breaks out once again. Michiru then begins hearing voices in her head telling her to help.

At the screening, voice actors Iwata Mitsuo and Hirano Fumi will MC an onstage event featuring some of the talent involved. For more info, visit the official Anime Tamago website!

title: Key's Planetarian Achieves OVA Crowdfunding Goal!
body:
The crowdfunding campaign for a new OVA adapting Key's visual novel Planetarian: The Reverie of a Little Planet has achieved its crowdfunding goal of 30 million yen!

Celebrating its 15th anniversary this year, the original game was released on Nov. 29, 2014. An original net animation of the same name and an anime movie titled Planetarian: Storyteller of the Stars followed in 2016.

The upcoming OVA, to be titled Planetarian~Snow Globe, is a prequel to the main story. Inspired by one of the light novel adaptations by Suzumoto Yuichi and Komatsu Eeji, it takes place in a world where humanity is witnessing the demise of the much anticipated Space Exploration Project. Hoshino Yumemi, a companion robot at the planetarium in the Flowercrest department store, ignores her orders and abandons her post to fulfil a promise made 10 years previously.

Tsuda Naokatsu, who directed the previous anime adaptations, will serve as supervisor while Takechi Hitomi will handle character design, and Yasukawa Shougo the scripts. It will be animated by Studio Okuru to Noboru.

The crowdfunding campaign is still underway and has also announced a stretch goal of 40 million yen. If achieved, it will allow the creative team to increase the length of the OVA.

title: Anime Site Collaboration Project Vol. 20: Kinema Citrus
body:
With anime more popular than ever all over the world, we sat down with some of the people who actually produce it to hear some of their thoughts about the production process and a few behind the scenes stories too. This interview series is a collaborative project between Japanese language news site Anime! Anime!, Tokyo Otaku Mode, and Chinese language sites Bahamut and Manrenzhi.

You can check out all the other interviews here.
******************************************

Anime Site Collaboration Project
Anime Production Studios Gaining Global Attention and Paving the Way to the Future Vol. 20: Kinema Citrus Part 1

Kinema Citrus‚Äô representative works: Made in Abyss, Revue Starlight, The Rising of the Shield Hero, Tokyo Magnitude 8.0, etc.

Our challenges are there on the screen. Kinema Citrus‚Äô power 11 years after its foundation

Kinema Citrus has produced hit after hit including such popular series as Made in Abyss, Revue Starlight, and The Rising of the Shield Hero. Only founded in 2008, it‚Äôs still a young studio. Is there some secret to their success? We visited Kinema Citrus to ask them and found the studio to be full of young, energetic staff. The answer seems to lie in that powerful environment. Also, they‚Äôre pushing ahead with bold new production methods. Kinema Citrus is primed to become a representative studio of the next generation.

How do the staff members go about their work? We sat down with Shinnosuke Harada from the digital department, and animator/character designer Hiroyuki Saita to find out.

[Interview/composition = Tadashi Sudo]





‚ñ† Kinema Citrus‚Äô strength: everyone pushing themselves and giving it their all

- Could you tell us a little about how you came to join Kinema Citrus?

Shinnosuke Harada: I came to it late. I freelanced after university and then joined the anime industry at 27. At first I was in the anime photography section. That lasted about two years. I was interested in production, and just when I was wondering about applying somewhere Kinema Citrus was the only place hiring. I‚Äôve been here five years now. I‚Äôm 32.

- What is it that you do now?

Harada: I‚Äôm attached to production. Mainly coloring and 2D work, designing posters that show up in the background, etc. I‚Äôd like to move into producing in the future.

I also manage the digital department. As I‚Äôm cheerful around the computers, digital animation included, I‚Äôm taking charge of the transition from paper to digital, preparing for introduction and setting up meetings to create formats.

Hiroyuki Saita: I work in the animation department where we handle character design. At Kinema Citrus we‚Äôre working on Kuma Miko: Girl Meets Bear and Revue Starlight.

- What made you want to get into the anime industry?

Saita: I started watching anime in high school and fell in love with it then.

- Were you good at drawing back then?

Saita: No, I couldn‚Äôt draw at all. I feel like I only started practicing when I joined a specialist school. Around the third year of high school, a classmate I got on well with handed round a sketchbook for everyone to draw in and that‚Äôs when I started drawing. And I fell in love with drawing then. Everyone said they wanted to go to a school with an anime department, but in the end it was only me who went (lol).

- How did you come to work on the character design for Kuma Miko: Girl Meets Bear?

Saita: Freelance animator Hisayuki Tabata invited me to work on the opening titles for Yuyushiki and that‚Äôs how I got together with Kinema Citrus. Little by little they started giving me more work, and then they asked me to work on character design for Kuma Miko: Girl Meets Bear.

- For young people who say they want to become animators and work on character design, you‚Äôd support them enthusiastically, like ‚Äúgo ahead, do it!‚Äù?

Saita: If you like it then I think it‚Äôs good to go on challenging yourself.

- What sort of people do well?

Saita: I have no idea! (lol). Even those who are no good at all in the beginning can become extremely proficient after a few years. But I don‚Äôt know what it is that makes someone good.

- You‚Äôre both still young, but as for the employees and contractors in general you‚Äôre a pretty young studio.

Saita: Speaking for the animation department, we‚Äôre mostly in our 20s.

Harada: You‚Äôre at the upper end too. I turned 32 this April and I‚Äôm one of the oldest in production. Of course, we have some veterans in their 40s and 50s, but about half are in their early 20s so yeah we‚Äôre a pretty young studio.

- So that‚Äôs your trademark. It must have advantages?

Saita: I mean it in a nice way, but they all work hard for us. I feel like everyone is pushing themselves and giving it their all. We get some amazing frames, don‚Äôt we?

‚ñ† Don‚Äôt sleep on Kinema Citrus

- Could we ask a little about your work? You‚Äôve produced some cool series like Made in Abyss,* Starlight Revue*, and The Rising of the Shield Hero. How did that happen? How did you pick them? You must have picked them, right?

Harada: More than anyone else, we‚Äôre very conscious that you have to protect the quality. CEO Muneki Ogasawara has always encouraged that in his career and now it feels like it‚Äôs coming to fruition in the film. Maybe (lol).

Saita: Young people have a lot of passion. They‚Äôre all knuckling down and making stuff.

- Is there one of Kinema Citrus‚Äô works that you‚Äôd particularly recommend?

Harada: Hard question. In the beginning I only knew about Kuma Miko: Girl Meets Bear. (lol). It‚Äôs from the early days but also Tokyo Magnitude 8.0.

Saita: You watched it in real time.

Harada: I‚Äôm not good with good stories. I cry (lol). Tokyo Magnitude 8.0 really got to me, I still like it now.

- That was the origin of Kinema Citrus.

Harada: I think that‚Äôs because it has that spiritual quality, but if you ask Ogasawara he might tell you you‚Äôre wrong (lol). Then there‚Äôs Barakamon. I feel like we have a real variety now. It‚Äôs a little different from where we started, because people have changed.

- What do you think, Mr. Saita?

Saita: Speaking for myself, the revue scenes from Revue Starlight which I worked on. Koide, a natural born animator at Kinema, handled it. He handled the whole thing and the quality is amazing.

- The Rising of the Shield Hero has been a big hit recently both in Japan and abroad. How did you manage that and what are you hoping for in the future?

Harada: Can I just speak for myself a minute? What indeed. (lol). There‚Äôs work I want to carry on with. The show we have going now, we haven‚Äôt exhausted the source material. We‚Äôve been talking about what to do after that. We‚Äôve worked so hard making it that we want to be able to continue. We‚Äôll keep going, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôll say. (lol).

Maybe we‚Äôre more popular overseas. If you asked if we planned it that way from the beginning, then I think we achieved the objective. There are times when you stray from the plan on purpose, to avoid predictability, and people tell you it‚Äôs very ‚ÄúKinema.‚Äù The drama really feels real.

‚ñ† Introduction of digital production, the frontline of production at Kinema Citrus

- Around how many people are involved in-house right now?

Harada: Other than here (the Ogikubo HQ), we have another studio at Nishi-Ogikubo. It‚Äôs really fulfilling. Here we do coloring to finishing. We also do in-betweens and have a section dedicated to checks. We have about 10 in-betweeners. T2studio (Takahashi Production) handle photography. Color coordination is 50/50. Hiroyuki mentioned Koide before who works with him in animation, he wears many hats and can do animation direction and character design.

Saita: That‚Äôs right. Producing and key animation too.

Harada: There are some who can do producing and key animation, but I think you can count them on one hand.

Saita: Around five, maybe?

Harada: With the personnel we have now, and the ones who will join us later, as we train them up and the numbers increase, I can see us being able to do a whole episode in-house. We‚Äôre aiming for that now. As for production, including the line producer, there are about 20 of us.

- Seems like you‚Äôre really growing.

Harada: I think we have to. Looking a little further off, in 5 to 10 years time, I think we‚Äôll have increased the lines.

- What about the male/female balance?

Saita: Are there more men in production?

Harada: A few. But, the numbers of women are really increasing. There were more women last year than the year before. Last year there were a few.

- You mentioned that you‚Äôre transitioning from paper and pencil to drawing on tablets and digital animation. How far along are you with that?

Harada: It seems like Ogasawara wanted to start before I joined the company but they couldn‚Äôt do it as well as they wanted. When I was in charge of Made in the Abyss, Satoshi Mori was running a digital animation studio in Gifu called Giftanimation. I took advantage of that too.

In the beginning I thought it would be easy. We wouldn‚Äôt need to send materials or travel far outside of work. But once we started, the production assistant‚Äôs job became much more difficult and complicated. We had to digitalize or we couldn‚Äôt go on. I wanted to do it because it had its upsides too. We tried out several kinds of production methods with Mori. We tried to do the animation of episode 13 of Made in Abyss digitally as far as we could. There were so many problems, but with the experience we gained The Rising of the Shield Hero was about 60% digital from episode 3.

- What was the reaction from the animators who are actually drawing it?

Harada: Even at Kinema Citrus, there were a lot of difficulties when we were trying to proceed with digital animation. It was Saita who explained to us how difficult it was during the meetings.

Saita: When Kinema Citrus was talking about going full digital, Kinema proposed the equipment and software, and the people who‚Äôd been using it so far could use it but for the people who had never used it before, even if they understood the terminology, they had no idea how to use it efficiently. Files were all over the place, checks were a pain. We started talking about what we could do about it. It was at that point that we needed to make some rules.

Harada: You draw a little, and then if there‚Äôs a problem you go back. I feel like we‚Äôve finally got there now.

Saita: To that extent we came up with the rules and then we were standing at the start line. (lol)

Harada: In the beginning, Saita said that because we‚Äôre doing this at Kinema we needed to put out quality work while creating a system where the amount of work done in a day wouldn‚Äôt change from the paper days. Since then there have been a lot of problems, and we solved them, so I think it will go well from now on.

I‚Äôm in production, Saita is in animation, but because we meet properly to talk through problems we can apply the ideas to the work. Kinema‚Äôs strength is that when something happens we can come up with a solution.

- You must work well as a team?

Harada: I think we‚Äôve finally perfected a system now. Thinking about the Kinema of 10 or 20 years time, I want the employee turnover to fall. If someone quits, you have to start over from scratch. As we‚Äôre finally perfecting digital animation after such a long process, if someone leaves we‚Äôll have to start again from there. It‚Äôll never get finished.

If we want them to stay, we need to think about a new production method from the point of view of working practices and conditions. Up to now we‚Äôve relied on freelancers but that won‚Äôt be possible in future generations. When it goes digital, companies will need to maintain equipment, that will cost money, and to use it properly will require people in the office continually doing good work. We need to change the anime industry, and make sure people stay in it.

‚ñ† Thanks to Twitter, you can participate in the Revue Starlight animation from overseas



- Are there any employees from overseas at Kinema Citrus?

Saita: Someone joined this year.

Harada: From other parts of Asia, but yes there are. There‚Äôs someone from China working in production. He joined the company right out of technical school.

Saita: Last year we had a girl from France intern with us to train in animation.

- Would you like to recruit more staff from abroad if the opportunity arose?

Harada: There‚Äôs no need to restrict yourself to people with Japanese citizenship. There might be a language barrier, but that‚Äôs not such an issue for animators.

Saita: It might be difficult with the language problem in production where communication is key, but it doesn‚Äôt really matter for animation. I taught an in-betweener from Taiwan once, but it wasn‚Äôt any different than teaching someone from Japan. The conversation might have been a little halting, but the passion was the same. Maybe, the overseas students are keener even (lol).

Harada: If you‚Äôve left your country and come to Japan just for that then you must have real resolve.

Saita: I think that‚Äôs probably true.

- Japanese anime is really popular overseas, have you had any responses from international viewers?

Harada: You really get a lot on Twitter.

Saita: Yes. Ogasawara gets a lot of responses to Revue Starlight on his Twitter feed. We get fan letters from overseas too. Made in Abyss is really popular overseas.

- Do you make the shows with overseas fans in mind?

Saita: No.

Harada: I don‚Äôt either. Rather than country, I think it‚Äôs better to say anime fandom. Rather being aimed at someone in particular, someone watching, someone who is interested, even if it‚Äôs just one person watching a lot that‚Äôs enough. Come, wherever you‚Äôre coming from (lol). Wherever you‚Äôre from, fight.

- What if someone offered you work overseas? ‚ÄúHey, come do character design for us!‚Äù, would you do it?

Saita: Sure! Though I don‚Äôt know if they want Japanese anime style overseas.

- I think you‚Äôd be OK across Asia.

Saita: I see illustrations from illustrators all over the world on Twitter, etc., and they‚Äôre almost identical to ones by Japanese illustrators, it‚Äôs amazing! We‚Äôve got animators from overseas working on key animation for us right now.

Harada: There are a few people working on Revue Starlight overseas. Ogasawara put out a want ad on his Twitter.

- Do you have anything to say to international fans?

Saita: Please watch Made in Abyss!

Harada: Your expectations are high but I think we can meet them. The anime production method is taking a step forward, so look out for that.

‚ñ† Doing all kinds of things, Kinema Citrus‚Äô future



- Could we ask a little about the future?

Saita: I want to make a hit! (lol). ‚ÄúThis is our masterpiece‚Äù - that kind of thing!

Harada: Me too. Something that will become a pillar we can build the company around so it can continue.

Saita: Like Dragon Ball for Toei, or Gundam for Sunrise.

Harada: If we can stabilize just by doing that, then we‚Äôll be able to train people too. I want to get rid of all the bad stories you hear about the anime production environment. To do that requires money though, so we need a big hit that can support us. We‚Äôve made a lot of good shows, but we need to take it further.

- Can I ask a big question? Where do you think Japanese anime is headed? Are there any trends?

Saita: Hmm, what‚Äôs going to happen? I‚Äôd like to know. If I knew that I could make a hit!

- What about pictures? Once there was a time that lines had really increased, but these days they‚Äôre pretty slim.

Saita: There are a lot of motion heavy shows lately so the lines have become simpler. I grew up loving bishoujo anime so my lines are a little bigger (lol).

Harada: I grew up watching movies and TV drama so I think if you can make something that has real soul so that people can get lost in the story then they‚Äôll keep coming back to it. That‚Äôs somewhere between a hope and prediction.

Saita: Recently, people have been remaking old properties. We‚Äôve gone back a little to the way things used to look. So you could say that‚Äôs the trend. However, Kinema doesn‚Äôt have a characteristic kind of show. We make all kinds of things. We even do fantasy - anything.

Harada: There‚Äôs space for everything so you can make anything. It‚Äôs good to maintain diversity. You get more experience by making different kinds of shows. In a company with a broad outlook, animators can become all-rounders and I think that‚Äôs a good thing.

- Thank you.

Harada: Finally, I‚Äôd just like to announce that we‚Äôve started recruiting new graduates for this year‚Äôs intake. We‚Äôre doing an orientation session for the first time. We want to strengthen recruitment, production, and animation. It doesn‚Äôt matter where you‚Äôre from, or how old you are. We want to make edgy work. If you‚Äôre the kind of person who can open their own doors, please come and knock on ours. We‚Äôd love to work with you. Though, as we‚Äôre only going to get bigger, it would be really great to find some people with drive.

title: Legend of the Galactic Heroes: Die Neue These Seiran Releases 2-Minute Trailer!
body:

title: Kimetsu no Yaiba to Make 2.5 Debut With 2020 Stage Play!
body:
Popular fantasy manga Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba will be making its 2.5D debut with a stage play that will run from January 2020 in Tokyo and Hyogo!

It has been confirmed that Suemitsu Kenichi is handling the script and direction, and Wada Syunsuke will be creating the music.

Based on the manga by Gotouge Koyoharu, Kimetsu no Yaiba follows kindhearted charcoal seller Kamado Tanjirou, whose life changes forever when his family is attacked by demons, leaving only him and his sister alive. In order to return his sister (who is now a demon) to her former state and avenge his family, Tanjirou sets out on a dangerous journey.
